page.title: 02LANGLEY BARONY,HAYDON BRIDGE
page.content: From 1873 when work first began,up to 1893, 40,761 tonnes of lead were extracted from the{mines.}There were three main{lead}veins; the Joicey shaft,St.Andrew's vein and Bewick vein Of these, the Bewick vein was the largest and was 4,400 ft.long and about 175 ft.wide.Today, all that remains of a once-valuable mine are two{spoil heaps.}These are heaps of waste and mud which came up with the lead.these heaps are very valuable,however and were last estimated to be worth 5 million pounds The heaps are valuable because of the {lead}and{barytes}they still contain. Various companies have taken interest in the heaps, and plan to extract the {lead}and{barytes}which is used on{oil {rigs.}
